sec.p: EO of A. millefolium showed remarkable antifungal activity against all plant fungi tested ( Table 4) at 5 ÂµL (1000 ppm/disc). It exhibited an inhibitory result on the development of R. stolonifer (65.7%) V. dahliae (56.3%), C. gloeosporioides (60.9%), Botrytis cinerea (50.8%), and Aspergillus niger (40.7%). The inhibitory effects might be related to the presence of mono- (55.7%) and sesquiterpenes (36.5%) in the EO [ 23].

The MICs defined as the deepest concentrations of the EO that allows for full progress inhibition of R. stolonifer, V. dahliae, C. gloeosporioides, B. cinerea, and A. niger were 1.6, 3.1, 3.4, 3.6, and 4.7 mg/mL, respectively ( Table 5). R. stolonifer was discovered to be the greatest sensitive fungal pathogens towards the A. millefolium EO.
